definitions: small in degree, amount, or intensity; not considerable or substantial
delicate in build or structure; having a thin, slender physique
of little importance or significance; trivial or negligible in nature
examples: There was a slight improvement in her condition overnight
He noticed a slight change in the room's temperature
Her slight frame made her look younger than she was
The slight boy struggled to carry the heavy boxes
It was only a slight mistake that didn't affect anything
She took slight offense at his casual remark

definitions: gracefully thin; slender in an attractive or healthy way
small in amount, degree, or proportion; barely sufficient
having very little likelihood or probability of success
examples: She maintained a slim figure through regular exercise
The slim silhouette of the tower dominated the skyline
The company operates on slim profit margins these days
They won by a slim majority of just two votes
His chances of winning the election are extremely slim
There's only a slim possibility we'll finish on time

definitions: covered with or producing a slippery, viscous substance; wet and slippery
disgustingly obsequious or morally repugnant; unpleasantly ingratiating
examples: The rocks near the river were slimy with algae
She touched the slimy surface of the snail's shell
That slimy salesman tried to overcharge us for everything
His slimy behavior made everyone uncomfortable at work

definitions: having a smooth surface that causes sliding or loss of grip; difficult to hold
not to be trusted; evasive and unpredictable in character or behavior
difficult to grasp mentally; elusive or hard to define precisely
examples: The bathroom floor was slippery after the shower
Be careful on the slippery ice outside the building
He's a slippery character who never keeps his promises
The slippery politician avoided answering direct questions
The concept of consciousness is a slippery philosophical problem
It's a slippery distinction between right and wrong here

definitions: in the process of losing one's grip, footing, or secure position
gradually declining in performance, quality, or control over time
examples: His slipping grip on the rope worried the other climbers
She felt her slipping balance on the narrow ledge
The company's slipping market share concerned the investors greatly
His slipping memory became more noticeable with age

definitions: having a surface that angles upward or downward; not level or flat
examples: The sloped roof helped the rain run off efficiently
They built their house on sloped terrain overlooking the valley

definitions: having a surface or line that inclines gradually; not perpendicular or level
examples: The sloping garden led down to the river below
She wrote in sloping handwriting that leaned to the right

definitions: lacking care, precision, or neatness; carelessly and untidily done
excessively emotional or sentimental in a weak or silly way
wet and messy; containing too much liquid or moisture
examples: His sloppy handwriting was difficult to read clearly
The report contained several sloppy errors and typos
The movie's sloppy romance scenes made audiences cringe uncomfortably
She hated sloppy displays of affection in public
The sloppy conditions on the field affected the game
He served sloppy joe sandwiches at the casual party

definitions: moving or operating at a low speed; not quick or fast
taking a longer time than usual or expected; not prompt
not quick to understand, think, or learn; mentally dull
showing a time earlier than the correct time
examples: The slow traffic made her late for the meeting
The old computer runs very slow compared to newer models
Business has been slow during the winter months recently
The slow progress frustrated everyone working on the project
He was slow to understand the complex mathematical concepts
Don't be slow to recognize good opportunities when they appear
My watch is running five minutes slow this morning
The kitchen clock has been slow for several weeks

definitions: slow-moving or inactive; lacking energy, alertness, or vigor
showing little growth or activity; performing below normal levels economically
examples: She felt sluggish after eating the heavy lunch meal
The sluggish response time of the server frustrated users
The sluggish economy worried investors and policy makers alike
Sales remained sluggish throughout the third quarter this year

definitions: spoken indistinctly with sounds running together; not clearly articulated
examples: His slurred speech indicated he had been drinking heavily
The patient's slurred words worried the doctor about stroke

definitions: having or showing a cunning and deceitful nature; wily or crafty
showing in a playful way that you know something secret
examples: The sly fox outsmarted all the hunters in the forest
His sly manipulation of the facts deceived many people
She gave him a sly wink across the crowded room
There was a sly humor in his seemingly innocent comments

definitions: of limited size, amount, or extent; not large or big
of minor importance, significance, or power; insignificant or trivial
young in age; used especially when referring to children
examples: The small apartment was perfect for a single person
She ordered a small coffee to go with breakfast
It's just a small problem that we can fix quickly
Even small contributions can make a significant difference overall
When I was small, we lived near the ocean
Small children need constant supervision and care from adults

definitions: of lesser size when compared to something else; more small
examples: The smaller bedroom would work better as an office
We need smaller portions to reduce food waste here

definitions: fairly or somewhat small; smaller than average but not extremely small
examples: They live in a smallish town outside the capital city
The smallish crowd still generated enthusiasm for the cause

definitions: having or showing quick intelligence or mental alertness; clever
clean, tidy, and stylish in appearance; fashionably elegant
quick, forceful, and usually painful; sharp or severe
examples: The smart student solved the puzzle in record time
It was smart of you to save money for emergencies
She looked smart in her new business suit today
The restaurant has a smart, modern interior design throughout
The smart slap left a red mark on his cheek
He walked at a smart pace to catch the train

definitions: violently broken into pieces; shattered or crushed completely
very drunk from alcohol; heavily intoxicated
examples: The smashed window needed immediate replacement for security reasons
They found smashed pottery scattered across the archaeological site
He got completely smashed at the office party last night
She was too smashed to remember how she got home

definitions: excellent or wonderful; extremely impressive or attractive
examples: The party was absolutely smashing with perfect decorations everywhere
She looked smashing in her red evening gown tonight

definitions: giving off or characterized by a particular odor or scent
examples: The smelling salts revived the fainting woman quickly
Fresh smelling laundry hung on the line outside today

definitions: having a strong, unpleasant smell; malodorous or stinking
examples: The smelly garbage needed to be taken out immediately
His smelly socks were left on the bedroom floor

definitions: having or wearing a smile; showing pleasure, amusement, or affection
examples: The smiling faces in the photograph brought back memories
Her smiling expression made everyone feel welcome and comfortable

definitions: strongly attracted to or in love with someone; infatuated
severely affected by something overwhelming; struck hard
examples: He was completely smitten with her from their first meeting
The smitten teenager wrote poetry about his crush daily
The region was smitten by drought for three consecutive years
She was smitten with guilt after the terrible accident

definitions: preserved or flavored by exposure to smoke from burning wood
having dark tinting like smoke; used especially of glass
examples: The smoked salmon appetizer was served with cream cheese
They enjoyed smoked brisket at the barbecue restaurant yesterday
The car's smoked windows provided privacy from onlookers outside
He wore smoked glasses to protect his sensitive eyes

definitions: producing little or no smoke when burned or operated
examples: The new smokeless fuel reduces air pollution significantly overall
They switched to smokeless tobacco products for health reasons

definitions: producing or giving off smoke; burning or smoldering
related to or designated for the use of tobacco products
providing undeniable proof or evidence; conclusively incriminating
examples: The smoking chimney indicated someone was home this evening
Smoking embers remained after the campfire was extinguished completely
The restaurant still had a smoking section until recently
He entered a smoking cessation program to quit tobacco
The detective found the smoking gun that proved his guilt
The leaked emails were the smoking gun in the scandal

definitions: filled with or smelling of smoke; producing much smoke
having a flavor or aroma reminiscent of smoke
having a gray color with dark tones like smoke
examples: The smoky room made everyone's eyes water uncomfortably tonight
The smoky atmosphere in the jazz club was authentic
The whiskey had a distinctive smoky flavor from peat
She loved the smoky taste of barbecued ribs immensely
Her smoky eye makeup was perfect for the evening
The cat had beautiful smoky gray fur throughout

definitions: burning slowly without flame but often with smoke and heat
showing suppressed but intense emotion, especially anger or passion
examples: The smoldering ruins were still dangerous to approach today
Smoldering coals remained in the fireplace all night long
His smoldering resentment finally erupted into open anger yesterday
She gave him a smoldering look across the room

definitions: having an even surface without roughness, bumps, or projections
happening without problems, difficulties, or delays; easy and uncomplicated
suavely charming in manner; polished and sophisticated in style
examples: The baby's smooth skin felt soft to the touch
The smooth marble floor reflected the overhead lights perfectly
The smooth transition between speakers impressed the audience greatly
Everything went smooth during the complicated merger process yesterday
His smooth talking convinced her to trust him completely
The smooth operator charmed everyone at the party tonight

definitions: made smooth or even by removing roughness or irregularities
examples: The smoothed surface was ready for painting this afternoon
Her smoothed hair looked elegant for the formal event

definitions: covered thickly or completely with something; buried under
overwhelmed by excessive attention, affection, or control
examples: The pancakes were smothered in maple syrup and butter
The garden was smothered with weeds after months of neglect
She felt smothered by her mother's constant attention daily
The smothered child rebelled against parental control eventually

definitions: oppressively confining or overwhelming; stifling or suffocating in effect
examples: The smothering heat made it difficult to breathe outside
Her smothering affection drove her children away from home

definitions: having or showing excessive pride in oneself or one's achievements; self-satisfied
examples: His smug expression after winning annoyed his competitors greatly
She gave a smug smile when proved right about everything

definitions: moved illegally into or out of a country or area
examples: The smuggled goods were confiscated at the border checkpoint
Police discovered smuggled weapons hidden in the shipping container

definitions: quick, energetic, and lively in movement or manner
irritable and sharp in speech or manner; bad-tempered
neat, stylish, and attractive in appearance or dress
examples: The snappy dialogue kept the audience engaged throughout the play
Make it snappy - we don't have much time left
Her snappy response surprised everyone at the meeting today
He's been snappy with everyone since morning started today
He looked snappy in his new tailored suit yesterday
The car has a snappy design that turns heads everywhere

definitions: done or performed in a stealthy, secret, or surreptitious way
examples: They planned a sneak attack on the enemy position
She took a sneak peek at her birthday presents

definitions: persistent but not openly acknowledged; secret or furtive
examples: She had a sneaking suspicion he was lying about everything
He harbored a sneaking admiration for his rival's work

definitions: doing things in a secret and unfair or dishonest way; furtive
examples: That was a sneaky trick to play on your friends
The sneaky cat stole food from the kitchen counter

definitions: showing the attitude of people who think they are better than others
examples: Her snobbish attitude alienated potential friends at the club
The restaurant had a snobbish atmosphere that made diners uncomfortable

definitions: showing too much curiosity about other people's affairs; prying
examples: The snoopy neighbor always watched everyone coming and going
Don't be so snoopy about their personal business matters

definitions: covered with snow or characterized by falling snow
pure white in color, resembling snow in appearance
examples: The snowy mountains looked beautiful in the morning sunlight
We stayed inside during the snowy weather last weekend
Her snowy hair framed her face beautifully and elegantly
The bird had snowy white feathers on its chest

definitions: short and turned up at the end, especially used of noses
examples: Her snub nose gave her face a youthful appearance always
The dog's snub nose made breathing difficult in hot weather

definitions: warm, comfortable, and protected from cold or bad weather
fitting closely or tightly; leaving little room for movement
examples: The cabin was snug and cozy during the winter storm
We felt snug by the fireplace with hot chocolate
The sweater was snug around her shoulders and arms
Make sure the lid fits snug to keep freshness

definitions: extremely wet; saturated or drenched with water or liquid
examples: His soaked clothes clung uncomfortably to his body outside
The soaked ground couldn't absorb any more rain water

definitions: containing or covered with soap; producing lather or suds
resembling a soap opera in being melodramatic or sentimental
examples: The soapy water made the floor dangerously slippery today
Her hands were still soapy from washing the dishes
The movie's soapy plot twists seemed unrealistic and forced
He hated the soapy dialogue in daytime television shows

definitions: rising rapidly or to a great height; ascending quickly
impressively high or grand in scope, style, or conception
examples: Soaring inflation rates worried economists and consumers alike nationwide
The eagle was soaring high above the mountain peaks
The cathedral's soaring arches inspired awe in all visitors
Her soaring vocals brought the audience to their feet

definitions: not affected by alcohol; not drunk or intoxicated
serious, sensible, and solemn in character or manner
quiet and sedate in color; not bright or showy
examples: He remained sober throughout the celebration last night completely
The sober driver took everyone home safely after midnight
His sober assessment of the situation proved accurate ultimately
The judge's sober demeanor commanded respect in the courtroom
She wore a sober gray suit to the funeral
The room was decorated in sober tones of brown

definitions: creating a more serious, sensible, or solemn mood or attitude
examples: The accident was a sobering reminder of safety importance
The sobering statistics revealed the true extent of poverty

definitions: willing to talk and engage in activities with others; friendly
examples: She's very sociable and makes friends easily everywhere she goes
The sociable atmosphere at the party helped everyone relax

definitions: relating to society or its organization and people's interactions
needing companionship and enjoying being with other people
relating to rank and status in society
examples: Social media has transformed how people communicate globally today
The study examined social factors affecting crime rates nationwide
Humans are social beings who need interaction with others
The social butterfly attended every party in town regularly
Her social position gave her influence in the community
Social mobility has decreased in recent decades significantly overall

definitions: advocating or following the principles of socialism as a political system
examples: The socialist party won several seats in parliament recently
She expressed socialist views on wealth distribution and equality
